ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.1_0: At one time in Vesāli, a householder who was a supporter of Venerable Ajjuka had two children living with him, a son and a nephew.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.3_0: “Sir, please assign this estate to the one of these two boys who has faith and confidence.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.4_0: Now at that time the householder’s nephew had faith and confidence.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.4_1: Ajjuka then told the boy about that boy,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.5_0: He then established a household with that wealth and made a gift.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.6_0: That householder’s son then said to Venerable Ānanda,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.7_0: “Venerable Ānanda, who is the father’s heir, the son or the nephew?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.9_0: “Sir, this Venerable Ajjuka has assigned our wealth to our housemate.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.10_0: “Venerable Ajjuka is no longer an ascetic.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.13_0: On that occasion Venerable Upāli was siding with Ajjuka,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.15_0: “Ānanda, when one is asked by the owner to assign an estate to so-and-so, and one does so, what has one committed?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.16_0: “One hasn’t committed anything, Sir, not even an act of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.17_0: “Venerable Ajjuka was asked by the owner to assign an estate to so-and-so, and he did so.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.18_0: There’s no offense for Venerable Ajjuka.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.1_0: At that time in Benares, a family that supported Venerable Pilindavaccha was harassed by criminals,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.2_0: and two of their children were kidnapped.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.3_0: Pilindavaccha brought the children back by his supernormal powers and placed them in a stilt house.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.4_0: People saw those children and said,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.5_0: “This is the greatness of Venerable Pilindavacchaʼs supernormal powers.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.6_0: and they placed confidence in him.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.7_0: But the monks complained and criticized him,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.8_0: “How can Venerable Pilindavaccha bring back children who have been kidnapped by criminals?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.9_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.10_0: “There’s no offense in the area of supernormal powers for one who possesses them.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.1_0: At one time the two monks Paṇḍaka and Kapila were friends.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.2_0: One was staying in a village and one at Kosambī.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.3_0: While on his way to the monk at Kosambī was walking along the road, but he was unable to hold his hands and feet.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.4_0: He took hold of it, thinking, “I’ll give it to the owners.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.7_0: Then a woman cowherd who had seen him crossing said,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.9_0: Thinking he was no longer an ascetic, he had sexual intercourse with her.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.10_0: When he arrived at Kosambī, he told the monks,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.12_0: “There’s no offense entailing expulsion for stealing,

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.49.1_0: At that time at Sāgalā, a monk who was a student of Venerable Daḷhika was plagued by discontent. He then took a turban from a shopkeeper and said to Daḷhika,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.49.2_0: “Sir, I’m no longer an ascetic; I’ll disrobe.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.49.5_0: After getting the turban brought, Venerable Daḷhika had it valued,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.49.6_0: and it was not worth five _māsaka_ coins.
